metadata.case_name: Workmen v. Management of Sugar Factory

facts.text: Respondent is a sugar factory where crushing season starts in first half of November each year.
From season 1956-57, respondent introduced incentive bonus scheme, continued with changes; consulted workmen at start of each season.
119 workmen employed as cane carrier mazdoors, supervisors or jamadars; all seasonal workmen.
For 1960-61 season starting November 1960, respondent proposed incentive bonus scheme with changes including 32,000 maunds crushing per day; unacceptable to workmen.
Union general secretary suggested alterations on November 7, 1960, including norm of 125,000 maunds per day for incentive.
No agreement on scheme; respondent alleged secretary incited go-slow due to changes.
Mild go-slow in cane carrier department from November 10, 1960.

From November 27, 1960, workmen deliberately and wilfully resorted to go-slow in combination, reducing average daily crushing to 26,000 maunds (actual 23,000-24,000 after adjustments), prejudicial, unsafe, fuel shortage risk.

General notice issued December 15, 1960, alleging go-slow instigated by secretary (admitted on Dec 6 before officials), detailing facts, requiring individual willingness by 4 PM Dec 17 to crush min 32,000 maunds avg daily excluding certain stoppages, else discharged from Dec 18.
Notice Dec 15 put on notice-board with translations, sent individually to cane carrier workmen, copy to union secretary.
Union secretary replied same day Dec 15, denying go-slow, false statements, called undertaking demand fantastic.
Three workmen gave undertakings; rest did not.
Situation deteriorated, workmen unruly, entered without tokens.

Notice at 5 PM Dec 17, 1960: 119 named cane carrier workers discharged for failing to record willingness per Dec 15 notice, struck off rolls from Dec 18, forfeit right to work place, liable to prosecution for trespass, final dues by Dec 19.
General strike from Dec 17 notice by union, continued to Dec 22, 1960.
Agreement Dec 22: refer discharged workmen case and strike wages to adjudication.

Joint application to government Dec 21, 1960; reference Jan 25, 1961 to tribunal: (1) Whether discharge of 119 workmen justified? If not, reinstatement/other relief? (2) Wages for strike period Dec 18 16:00 to Dec 22 08:00?
No enquiry by respondent as per standing orders before discharge.
Tribunal tried if go-slow Nov 27-Dec 15; respondent evidence (documentary, past performance) proved go-slow; appellants denied normal work.
Tribunal concluded go-slow proved, discharge justified; strike wages not pressed.
Past history: Go-slow complaints since 1950, court of enquiry 1950 found slow-down; notices/threats 1951-55; complaints 1955-58.
1959-60 season dispute on crushing amount, secretary admitted drop due to dissatisfaction with bonus.
Secretary admitted workmen meeting decided no extra effort if new scheme without consent.
Negotiations: respondent suggested 30,000 norm, union 29,500; no agreement.
Night weighment carts from mid 1959-60 increased crushing by 2,000-2,500 maunds/day.
Charts: Ex W-4 crushing speed 1954-55: 29,784; 1955-56: 30,520 (no incentive/night weigh); post-incentive higher.
Nov 10-26, 1960 crushing speed 29,859; Nov 27-Dec 15: 27,830 (drop over 2,000).

legal_issues.text: Whether tribunal misdirected itself on scope of reference: limited to justifying discharge for not giving undertaking, or could investigate go-slow?
Whether respondent could justify discharge before tribunal absent charge-sheets and enquiry per standing orders?
Whether tribunal's finding of go-slow Nov 27-Dec 15 perverse, ignoring relevant evidence?

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal scope limited to whether discharge for not giving undertaking justified; no jurisdiction over go-slow.
No charge-sheets or enquiry per standing orders; tribunal no jurisdiction on merits/go-slow.
Go-slow finding perverse; ignored relevant evidence; relied on actual crushing not speed; crushing speed miscalculated ignoring rest under Factories Act s.55.

respondent_arguments.text: Go-slow from Nov 10 mild, deliberate from Nov 27; proved by evidence, past performance, charts on crushing speed.
Notices Dec 15/17 together show discharge for go-slow; tribunal could investigate full merits absent enquiry.
32,000 maunds crushing speed normal excluding stoppages; exemption under Factories Act s.64(2)(d); night weighment increase justifies.

court_reasoning.text: Reference wide: 'whether discharge justified'; parties led evidence on go-slow; notices Dec 15/17 read together, real reason go-slow, not just undertaking failure; joint reference implied full scope.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal entitled to investigate go-slow as ground for discharge.

court_reasoning.text: Dec 15 notice first part was charge of go-slow; absent enquiry, employer can justify before tribunal on merits, no distinction defective/no enquiry; prevents delay/re-hearing.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal jurisdiction to go into facts; cited precedents followed.

court_reasoning.text: Go-slow finding not perverse; past history of go-slow; withdrawal extra efforts = go-slow; crushing speed relevant (Ex W-4, W-7); significant drop Nov 27-Dec 15 vs prior/ past; 32,000 reasonable; Factories Act exemption s.64(2)(d) over s.55, minor adjustment still drop evident.

holdings.text: Tribunal scope includes investigating go-slow as basis of discharge.
Absent enquiry, tribunal can examine merits; employer justifies on evidence.

precedents_cited.case_name: Indian Iron Steel Co. v. Their workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Employer can justify dismissal absent enquiry before tribunal on merits.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sasa Musa Sugar Works P. Limited v. Shobrati Khan
Phulbari Tea Estate v. Its Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Principle applies to s.10 reference even with defective enquiry.

precedents_cited.case_name: Punjab National Bank Limited v. Its Workman
Bharat Sugar Mills Limited v. Shri Jai Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Confirms tribunal decides merits absent enquiry.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shri Ram Swarath Sinha v. Belaund Sugar Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Labour Appellate Tribunal decision on enquiry omission.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference under s.10; approval under s.33 analogous; tribunal jurisdiction on merits absent enquiry.

statutes_cited.name: Factories Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Exemption for continuous cane crushing from rest intervals s.55; s.64(2)(d) overrides.

statutes_cited.name: Standing Orders
statutes_cited.relevance: Required enquiry before discharge; absent, tribunal examines.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; tribunal award upheld finding go-slow proved and discharge of 119 workmen justified; no wages for strike period as not pressed.

key_quotes.text: though in form the notice of December 17, 1960 reads as if the workmen were being discharged for not giving the undertaking as desired, the real basis of the notice of discharge of December 17, 1960 is the use of go-slow
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets notices; real ground for discharge.

key_quotes.text: it is open to him to justify the action before the tribunal by leading all relevant evidence before it... the tribunal would have jurisdiction not only to go into the limited questions... but also to satisfy itself on the facts
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rules on tribunal power absent domestic enquiry.

key_quotes.text: the conclusion that there was go-slow between November 27 and December 15 is not justified.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: In the circumstances the tribunal was justified in coming to the conclusion that the discharge was fully justified.
key_quotes.speaker: court
